contextId.information: Here "the earth" is used to represent the people on the earth. AT: "The people of the world are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "hands" represent God and his creative action. AT: "You" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Job referred to himself as his eye since it is with his eyes that he saw these things.  AT: "I have seen all this  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: my eye has seen all this

contextId.information: The soles of his feet represent the person who walks. AT:  "you examine the ground where I have walked"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you examine the ground where the soles of my feet have walked

contextId.information: Here the "spirit" refers to the whole person. AT: "turn yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Job refers to himself by his "spirit" to emphasize his inner emotions. He speaks of not having any strength left as if he were something that has been used up. AT: "I am consumed" or "I have lost all of my strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "their" refers to his friends. They are referred to by their "hearts" to emphasize their emotions. AT: "have kept them" or "have kept my friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the "heel" refers to the whole foot. AT: "will take hold of his foot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: will take him by the heel

contextId.information: The eye represents a person. AT: "Anyone who had seen him" or "The people who has seen him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "eyes" refers to the person. AT: "Let him see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Job imagines that the dead person will even enjoy the dirt that is put on him. This means the wicked person will even have a good death and a nice burial after a fulfilling life. "Clods" refer to the earth that covers the grave. AT: "He will enjoy being covered with the dirt of the valley" or "He will enjoy being buried in the dirt of the valley" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The clods of the valley will be sweet to him

contextId.information: Here "breast" refers to the mother. This implies that these orphans are still very young. This can be made explicit. AT: "young orphans out of their mothers' arms" or "fatherless infants from their mothers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "walls" refers to the whole house. AT: "in the houses of those evil men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: within the walls of those wicked men

contextId.information: Here "eye" refers to the whole person. AT: "the adulterer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The ears represent those who heard him, and the eyes represent those who saw him. AT: "after they heard what I told them ... after they saw me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: after their ears heard me ... after their eyes saw me

contextId.information: Here "my heart" represents Job. This phrase can be stated in active form. AT: "if I have been secretly attracted to them" or "if I have secretly desired to worship them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: if my heart has been secretly attracted

contextId.information: Here "my mouth" represents Job speaking. AT: "Truly I did not let myself sin" or "Truly, I did not sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Indeed, I have not even allowed my mouth to sin

contextId.information: The person is represented by his "soul." AT: "him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here people are represented by their "hands." AT: "not by humans" or "not by people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "hand" represents the entire person. AT: "He stops every man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: He stops the hand of every man
